thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: 50 state road trip: 50 historic and famous must-see homes
thread.title_full: 50 state road trip: 50 historic and famous must-see homes

title: 50 state road trip: 50 historic and famous must-see homes
text:
Alabama - Famed country singer Hank Williams Sr.’s childhood home in Georgiana is now a museum. Jeff Greenberg/Alabama Tourism Department Fullscreen Alaska - The Santa Claus House, located in North Pole, Alaska, spreads the spirit of Christmas all year with a 42-foot-tall Santa Claus sculpture and a team of reindeer. Santa Claus House Fullscreen Arizona - Taliesin West is a national historic landmark nestled in the desert foothills of the McDowell Mountains outside of Scottsdale and served at Frank Lloyd Wright’s winter home. Arizona Office of Tourism Fullscreen Arkansas - Johnny Cash’s boyhood home is a five-room house given to Ray Cash and his family in 1935. It is now owned by Arkansas State University and has been restored with the help of the Cash family. Arkansas Department of Parks and Tourism Fullscreen California - Once the private residence of publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst, Hearst Castle is now one of California’s most visited state parks. Visit California/Blaise Fullscreen Colorado - The Stanley Hotel in Estes Park, Colo., was the original home of F.O. Stanley (who owned and built the Stanley Steamer) and the inspiration for Stephen King’s The Shining during his stay in room 217. Visit Estes Park Fullscreen Connecticut - The Mark Twain House, a National Historic Landmark in Hartford, was the 19-room Victorian home of legendary author Samuel Clemens (Mark Twain), from 1874 to 1891, where he wrote his greatest works. Mark Twain House & Museum, Hartford, Conn. Fullscreen Delaware - Nemours Mansion and Gardens is a 300-acre country estate of the late industrialist and philanthropist Alfred I. duPont. visitdelaware.com Fullscreen Florida - In 1961, the Palm Beach Peanut Island nuclear bunker was built for then President John F. Kennedy as a safe haven. It was filled with gas masks and food supplies for 30 people in the event of a nuclear attack from Cuba. Palm Beach Maritime Museum Fullscreen Georgia - Atlanta is home to a boy who later grew up to change a nation. Visitors can check out the birth home of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., there. Georgia Tourism MLK Fullscreen Hawaii - Hanaiakamalama was the “mountain” home of Queen Emma Naea. Nestled on a lush plot of land off of the Pali Highway, the summer palace was used as Queen Emma’s cool retreat to avoid the high temperatures in Honolulu. Hawaii Tourism Authority (HTA) - Tor Johnson Fullscreen Idaho - Ernest Hemingway called the Sun Valley Lodge home during many visits to the Sun Valley area and ultimately finished his masterpiece, 'For Whom the Bell Tolls,' while staying there. Kevin Syms/Sun Valley Resort Fullscreen Illinois - In Springfield, visitors may tour Abraham Lincoln's home, visit his tomb and learn about his life at the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum. EnjoyIllinois.com Fullscreen Indiana - Right next to Illinois, explore the boyhood home of our 16th President at the Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial. Visit Indiana Fullscreen Iowa - The Grant Wood Studio in Cedar Rapids is where the famed artist lived and worked from 1924-1935. The light-filled loft is where he painted American Gothic and other works. Iowa Tourism Office Fullscreen Kansas - The Eisenhower Home in Abilene is where President Dwight D. Eisenhower spent his formative years with his five brothers from 1898 to 1911. Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks & Tourism Fullscreen Kentucky - Kentucky is the birthplace of Abraham Lincoln and the Abraham Lincoln Birthplace National Historical Park tells his story near Hodgenville. www.kentuckytourism.com Fullscreen Louisiana - Degas House was home to French Impressionist Master Edgar Degas 1872-1873, and he painted 18 works while residing in the home, including his first Impressionist painting and the only painting sold to a museum during his lifetime. New Orleans CVB Fullscreen Maine - A resident of Bangor, Stephen King's house is guarded with a wrought iron fence adorned with bats. Despite the home's mysterious facade, the author is actively involved in the community. Maine Office of Tourism Fullscreen Maryland - Explore the Baltimore home of Edgar Allan Poe, one of the world’s most famous writers. Visit Baltimore Fullscreen Massachusetts - Edith Wharton (1862-1937), author of Ethan Frome and House of Mirth, designed her own home and garden in Lenox and named it The Mount. Now a National Historic Landmark, The Mount is open to visitors from May through October. Mass Office of Travel & Tourism/John Seakwood Fullscreen Michigan - Michigan is the birthplace of the Model T and the modern automobile industry; visitors may take a ride in the Model T at Greenfield Village, part of The Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn. Pure Michigan Fullscreen Minnesota - Judy Garland’s childhood home on the outskirts of Grand Rapids is open for tours, as is the attached Judy Garland Museum, which houses memorabilia from her life and career. Paul Stafford, Explore Minnesota Tourism Fullscreen Mississippi - The Elvis Presley Birthplace and Museum in Tupelo gives visitors an opportunity to see where the King of Rock and Roll was born and raised. Visit Mississippi Fullscreen Missouri - Hannibal is not only the setting for one of Mark Twain’s most famous books, 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,' it is also where the author and humorist grew up. Luci Branyan/Missouri Division of Tourism Fullscreen Montana - Evel Knievel was born and raised in Butte. Every July, the town celebrates the legacy of its hometown daredevil by hosting the only extreme sports festival of its kind, Evel Knievel Days. Donnie Sexton, Montana Office of Tourism Fullscreen Nebraska - Visit the mansion of J. Sterling Morton, founder of Arbor Day, at the Arbor Lodge State Historical Park in Nebraska City. Hope Jewell-Vinson Fullscreen Nevada - The home of industrialist John Mackay is open for tours in Virginia City. Mackay was one of the four mine owners, known as the Bonanza Kings, who ran the silver boomtown of Virginia City in the late 19th century. travelnevada.com Fullscreen New Hampshire - Robert Frost, one of the nation’s most acclaimed poets, lived at this simple two-story farmhouse in Derry from 1900-1911. Many of his poems are attributed to memories from his years here. Ellen Edersheim Fullscreen New Jersey - The Historic Ballantine House, now part of Newark Musuem, is an 1885 Victorian mansion that belonged to beer magnate John Holme Ballantine. Brand USA/Amon Focus Fullscreen New Mexico - Taos Pueblo, a UNESCO World Heritage site, is the oldest, continuously inhabited community in North America, constructed between 1000 and 1450 A.D. New Mexico True Fullscreen New York - The house that Louis Armstrong shared with his wife until his death in 1971 was bequeathed to the city of New York by his wife, and now hosts the a museum to the jazz musician. Julienne Schaer/NYC & Company Fullscreen North Carolina - Thomas Wolfe immortalized his boyhood home, a rambling Victorian boardinghouse in Asheville, in the epic 1929 novel 'Look Homeward, Angel.' N.C. Department of Cultural Resources Fullscreen North Dakota - Maltese Cross Ranch cabin was Theodore Roosevelt’s retreat in the North Dakota badlands. ND Tourism Fullscreen Ohio - Visitors to the Hayes Presidential Center in Fremont enter the Spiegel Grove estate through a set of original White House gates, which provide access to the home, library, museum and tomb of 19th U.S. President Rutherford B. Hayes. Tourism Ohio Fullscreen Oklahoma - The Dog Iron Ranch in Oologah is the site of the log-walled, two-story home where famed Cherokee humorist and film star Will Rogers was born in 1879. Lori Duckworth/Oklahoma Tourism Fullscreen Oregon – Astoria, Oregon, is the home to the cult classic movie, 'The Goonies.' Travel Oregon - Sumio Koizumi Fullscreen Pennsylvania - Located in historic Gettysburg, Eisenhower National Historic Site is the home and farm of General and President Dwight D. Eisenhower, which served as a weekend retreat and meeting place for world leaders. Destination Gettysburg Fullscreen Rhode Island - The Breakers is the summer cottage of the Vanderbilt family. Gavin Ashworth Fullscreen South Carolina - South Carolina’s only presidential site, a distinctive circa-1871 Italian villa-style residence in Columbia, was home to a 14-year-old boy named “Tommy” Woodrow Wilson. Discover South Carolina Fullscreen South Dakota - Visit the historic homes of beloved 'Little House on the Prairie' author Laura Ingalls Wilder in charming De Smet. South Dakota Department of Tourism Fullscreen Tennessee - Elvis’ Graceland in Memphis gives visitors an inside look on how the King of Rock n’ Roll lived. Tennessee Department of Tourism Fullscreen Texas - Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park is in the Hill Country of Central Texas and protects the birthplace, home and ranch of Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th President of the United States. Texas Parks and Wildlife Fullscreen Utah - The Beehive House, the home of former Mormon leader Brigham Young, is one of the tourist attractions that is part of Temple Square in Salt Lake City. AP Photo/Douglas C. Pizac Fullscreen Vermont - The President Calvin Coolidge State Historic Site in Plymouth was the birthplace and childhood home of the 30th President of the United States. Dennis Curran/VermontVacation.com Fullscreen Virginia - Visit the set of 'The Waltons' on Walton's Mountain in Schuyler. This is the childhood town where the author of the series, Earl Hamner Jr., grew up. Virginia Tourism Corporation Fullscreen Washington - English Camp, San Juan Island National Historical Park, housed the British garrison during the “Pig War.” It’s the only national park in the USA that flies the British flag. San Juan Islands Visitors Bureau Fullscreen West Virginia - Grafton is the birthplace of Anna Jarvis, who established the first Mother’s Day in 1914 to honor her mother, Anna Maria Reeves Jarvis, for her Civil War humanitarian work. Anna Jarvis House Fullscreen Wisconsin - As the hometown and winter quarters of the famous Ringling Brothers, Baraboo attracts visitors today with Circus World Museum. Circus World Fullscreen Wyoming - The first JC Penney store was opened inKemmerer. Originally called theGolden Rule Store, the first store of the mega chain was opened in 1902 by James Cash Penney, in his hometown, where you can still see his house. Wyoming Office of Tourism Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Delaware - Nemours Mansion and Gardens is a 300-acre country estate of the late industrialist and philanthropist Alfred I. duPont. (Photo: visitdelaware.com)
723 CONNECT 170 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Take a trip through American history by visiting the home of one of country's great citizens in each state of the union, from policitians (Abraham Lincoln has three separate home musuems) to the artistic (two of Elvis' homes make the list) to the industrious (there's only one Henry Ford homeplace, in Michigan). One of the homes on our list could be over a thousand years old. Any guesses?
Want to take another trip of all 50 states?
Can't miss stops:
Alabama - The Unclaimed Baggage Center has become a must-see attraction, with everything from moose antlers to wedding gowns to suits of armor. Meg McKinney Fullscreen Alaska - Visit the Denali Kennels at Denali National Park in summer for demonstrations of a team of dogs pulling a ranger around a gravel track. Daniel A. Leifheit Fullscreen Arizona - Check out the sunset at Yavapai Point on the South Rim of Grand Canyon National Park. National Park Service Fullscreen Arkansas - At the Quarts Crystal Mines, you keep what you find.More than 70,000 diamonds have been found since Crater of Diamonds State Park was established in 1972. Arkansas Tourism Fullscreen California - The coolest thing about Torrey Pines State Natural Reserve is the topography, like the gorgeous cliffs that make for a photo-worthy backdrop. SanDiego.org Fullscreen Colorado - The summit of High Dune at Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve is the perfect spot for sand boarding. National Park Service Fullscreen Connecticut - The Brownstone Exploration & Discovery Park is designed in a flooded old brownstone quarry. You can climb up more than 70 feet, then zip line back down. Kindra Clineff Fullscreen Delaware - Winterthur Mansion, Garden and Library is the 175-room former DuPont family estate and home to the nation’s foremost collection of American antiques and collectibles. Delaware Tourism Office Fullscreen Florida - In the Gulf Coast Everglades, the most popular resident is the alligator. But did you know it's home to crocodiles, too? This is the only place in the world where you can see both. Peter Cross for Visit Florida Fullscreen Georgia - Pay a visit to Centennial Olympic Park, a 21-acre park filled with sculptures, water gardens and lavish scenery. In the center of it all: The Fountain of Rings. Georgia Department of Economic Development Fullscreen Hawaii - Eleven of the world's 13 climatic zones can be found on Hawaii. If you're into the lava thing, check out live ooze at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, home of the active Kilauea Volcano. Mark Wasser-HR Fullscreen Idaho - There’s nothing quite like fishing in the cool, clear waters of the Salmon River in Central Idaho. Paul Frantellizzi Fullscreen Illinois - A stop in Chicago isn’t complete without a trip to the Cloud Gate sculpture, better known as the “Bean." Its highly polished stainless steel exterior reflects Chicago’s famous skyline. Illinois Office of Tourism Fullscreen Indiana - Search for rare species of birds or fly kites on the sandy beach at Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore. The national lakeshore offers 45 miles of trails. National Park Service Fullscreen Iowa - The John and Mary Pappajohn Sculpture Park features a $40 million collection of the world's most celebrated artists, including White Ghost by Yoshitomo Nara. Iowa Tourism Office Fullscreen Kansas - The Museum at Prairiefire is the heartland outpost for the American Museum of Natural History and features rotating exhibitions from New York City. Overland Park Convention & Visitors Bureau Fullscreen Kentucky - Churchill Downs is open for tours year round, with times designated by the Kentucky Derby Museum, which is on the same grounds as the track. kentuckytourism.com Fullscreen Louisiana - Irvin Mayfield and the New Orleans Jazz Orchestra’s New Orleans Jazz Market features music education experiences, a New Orleans Jazz archive and tributes to current and past Jazz Masters. Brandt Vicknair Fullscreen Maine - View peregrine falcons soaring through Acadia National Park, where raptor volunteers usually spend from the summer working with the Peregrine Watch and HawkWatch programs. National Park Service Fullscreen Maryland - For some outstanding produce,meats, dairy, breads, flowers, collectibles and crafts, stop by the Baltimore Farmers' Market & Bazaar, Maryland’s largest producers-only market. Baltimore Office of Promotion & The Arts Fullscreen Massachusetts - The Lawn on D is an experimental, interactive 2.7-acre outdoor event space in South Boston. Check out the rotating exhibitions of public art or play games like bocce or ping-pong. Lawn on D Fullscreen Michigan - Explore Mackinac Island's scenic trails by foot, bike or horse-drawn carriage. Then, step inside Fort Mackinac to help fire a cannon, or stroll along the porch of the iconic Grand Hotel. Pure Michigan Fullscreen Minnesota - Stroll through 11 galleries of modern and contemporary art at theWalker Art Center, then check out the adjacent Minneapolis Sculpture Garden. Paul Stafford, Explore Minnesota Tourism Fullscreen MIssissippi - The Blues Trail marker at Dockery Farms is titled "Birthplace of the Blues?" for a good reason: It's a place where Charley Patton, Henry Sloan, Howlin' Wolf, Willie Brown, Tommy Johnson and Pops Staples all lived and played. Mississipi Tourism Fullscreen Missouri - Winding Brook Estate, about 30 minutes west of St. Louis, is a 17-acre lavender farm in the hills of the northern Ozarks. Sign up for a themed lunch. Missouri Division of Tourism Fullscreen Montana - This stunning view of Grinnell Lake is the reward after a bit of a hike up the Grinnell Glacier Trail at Glacier National Park. Donnie Sexton Fullscreen Nebraska - Carhenge, a replica of Britain’s Stonehenge, is made from 1940s and 1960s cars that are very nearly the same dimensions as the stones that make up the real thing. Carhenge Fullscreen Nevada - Step back in time to Vegas' mobster days at the Mob Museum, a showcase of all things organized crime. Courtesy of the Mob Museum Fullscreen New Hampshire - Drive through the Saco River covered bridge constructed in the 1800s. It’s one-quarter mile north of N.H. Route 16 on N.H. Route 153 in Conway Village. New Hampshire Division of Travel and Tourism Development Fullscreen New Jersey - Spend the day at the Valley Shepherd Creamery. Learn how the cheese is made at a cheese-making class on the farm. Valley Shepherd Creamery Fullscreen New Mexico - Ride the Sandia Peak Tramway (or hike) to the top of the iconic Sandia Peak at an elevation of 10,378 feet. Visitors can see for more than 100 miles to the west. Campbell Levy Fullscreen New York - Hush Tours' The Birthplace of Hip Hop tour takes you through Harlem and the “Boogie Down” Bronx, to show you some of the most important sites in the history of hip hop. Hushtours.com Fullscreen North Carolina - The Cape Hatteras Lighthouse is the tallest brick lighthouse in the USA, and it was built to help ships navigate the “Graveyard of the Atlantic.” National Park Service Fullscreen North Dakota - Drive along the Enchanted Highway for a glimpse of classic roadside art. North Dakota Tourism Fullscreen Ohio - Try your hand, or feet rather, at contra dancing (aka folk dancing) in Cuyahoga Valley National Park. Be sure to wear comfy shoes! National Park Service Fullscreen Oklahoma - On any given day you can drive down the main road of the Wichita Mountains Wildlife Refuge and see herds of bison on one side of the road and other wildlife species like the native longhorn cattle on the other. Gigi Ragland Fullscreen Oregon - Crater Lake will take your breath away. Cliffs rising almost 2,000 feet surround this deep, pure lake. It looks especially incredible on a foggy day. National Park Service Fullscreen Pennsylvania - There's nothing like walking into the Eastern State Penitentiary, a 19th century, gothic-style castle that thousands of hardcore criminals, like Al Capone and notorious bank robber “Slick Willie" Sutton, called home. Eastern State Penitentiary Fullscreen Rhode Island - Block Island can be defined by what it lacks: stoplights, McDonald’s, and Holiday Inns. Instead, the town of fewer than 1,000 year-round residents is jam packed with striking landscapes. Michael Melford Fullscreen South Carolina - Go birdwatching at Congaree National Park, which is set in a large hardwood forest featuring hiking trails, as well as creeks for canoeing and fishing. National Park Service Fullscreen South Dakota - The Black Hills Maze is two levels and 37,000 square feet worth of fun. Since it’s one of the world’s largest, plan on spending a decent amount of time here. Black Hills Maze Fullscreen Tennessee - Synchronous fireflies, the only species that coordinate their flashing patterns, live in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, and put on a natural spectacle for a two-week period in late May to mid-June. Tennessee Department of Tourist Development Fullscreen Texas - Head to Bracken Cave and join sunset tours (April-October) to watch the bats - up to 20 million of them - take flight for the night. San Antonio Convention & Visitors Bureau Fullscreen Utah - Although there are five national parks in Utah (aka The Mighty 5), if you had to choose one iconic image/thing to do in the Beehive State it would likely be to visit Arches National Park and to see Delicate Arch. Jacob W. Frank Fullscreen Vermont - Visit Ben & Jerry’s Factory to sample some of your faves. Ben & Jerrys Fullscreen Virginia - Stroll through Colonial Williamsburg’s Revolutionary City and stop by R. Charlton’s Coffeehouse to sample coffee, tea, or velvety chocolate. Colonial Williamsburg Fullscreen Washington - For a bit of extra luck, visit Rachel, a 700-pound, swine-shaped statue in Seattle's popular Pike Place Market, and rub her snout. Rest assured, any coins you donate to the piggy bank go straight to local nonprofits. Charlie Schuck Fullscreen West Virginia - Cross the pedestrian footbridge that links West Virginia and Maryland. National Park Service Fullscreen Wisconsin - The House on the Rock retreat, built atop a chimney of rock, opened to the public in 1960. Take a self-guided tour to see Titanic memorabilia, the world’s largest carousel and more than 200 fully furnished doll houses. House on the Rock Fullscreen Wyoming - A trip to Wyoming isn’t complete without a visit to Grand Teton National Park, home to glacier-chiseled peaks that rise 7,000 feet above the floor of Jackson Hole Valley. Four Seasons Resort & Residences Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide State secrets:
Alabama - Five Rivers Delta Museum in Spanish Fort is the ultimate place to soak up the natural beauty and incredible history of the region. Alabama Tourism Department Fullscreen Alaska - Visitors might be surprised to find natural mineral waters flowing in Alaska at Chena Hot Springs Resort near Fairbanks. The outdoor rock pool, on average 106 degrees Fahrenheit, is also a prime location for aurora borealis viewing in the winter. State of Alaska/Brian Adams Fullscreen Arizona - Established in 1937 by William Shirley Fulton, the Amerind Museum near Dragoon in southeastern Arizona tells the story of America's first people from Alaska to South America and from the last Ice Age to the present. Scott R. Davis/Arizona Office of Tourism Fullscreen Arkansas - Historic Washington State Park has a blacksmith shop where the first Bowie Knife was forged, weapons and print museums, residences and a steam-powered cotton gin. Arkansas Department of Parks and Tourism Fullscreen California - Located on Northern California's most remote coastline, Shelter Cove is a gateway to the Lost Coast. J.H.Klinger and www.Redwoods.info Fullscreen Colorado - Sink into the highest mountains ofsandin North America at Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve. Thedunes have been building and sifting for eons. Matt Inden, Colorado Tourism Office Fullscreen Connecticut - The Glass House is a 49 acre National Trust Historic Site thathonors the legacy of Philip Johnson and David Whitney, and offers14 artistic structures featuring the Glass House. Connecticut Office of Tourism Fullscreen Delaware - Experience the quiet rural escape of Trap Pond State Park, the most northern point for bald cypress trees. visitdelaware.com Fullscreen Florida - Florida Caverns State Park is one of the few state parks in the U.S. with dry, air-filled caves and is the only state park in Florida to offer cave tours to the public. Florida Department of Environmental Protection Fullscreen Georgia - Known as Georgia's "Little Grand Canyon," Providence Canyon has soil filled with pink, orange, red and purple hues that make a beautiful natural painting. Georgia Tourism Fullscreen Hawaii - A beautiful hike along the coast of Oahu with two trail heads from Waianae (south) and Mokuleia (north) both take hikers up to the western tip of the island, the site of an albatross sanctuary. Hawaii Tourism Authority (HTA)/Tor Johnson Fullscreen Idaho - Home to more than 1,300 acres of wine grape vineyards, 30 wine varietals, 51 wineries and award winning wines, Idaho’s wine industry is the state’s fastest-growing agricultural industry. Ray Gadd & Idaho Wine Commission Fullscreen Illinois - The quaint and quiet town of Galena comes alive on its Main Street for locals and travelers alike. Cozy shops line the street, with the Galena River on one side and rolling hills reminiscent of European countryside on the other. EnjoyIllinois.com Fullscreen Indiana - A beach in Indiana? The Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore is one of the best family beach destinations in the country. Visit Indiana Fullscreen Iowa - The Historic Park Inn Hotel in Mason City is the last remaining hotel designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in the world. Iowa Tourism Office Fullscreen Kansas - Quivira National Wildlife Refuge near Stafford was established in 1955 to provide and protect vital habitat for migratory waterfowl in the Central Flyway. Kansas Department of Wildlife, Parks & Tourism Fullscreen Kentucky - Princess Falls is one of several beautiful waterfalls inside the Big South Fork National River and Recreation Area, which covers 125,000 acres and features scenic bluffs, gorges and plenty of outdoor recreation activities. www.kentuckytourism.com Fullscreen Louisiana - The park rangers at the New Orleans Jazz National Historic Park are all musicians, and visitors can watch them perform or participate in jazz yoga weekly. NewOrleansOnline.com Fullscreen Maine - You can experience the "bean-hole-beans," one of the state's traditional dishes cooked by its Native American populations, at Maine Forest & Logging Museum at Leonard's Mills in Bradley. Maine Office of Tourism Fullscreen Maryland - Climb the 227 steps of Baltimore’s Washington Monument, America’s first major monument to honor George Washington. Mount Vernon Place Conservancy Fullscreen Massachusetts - Gloucester Harbor north of Boston is one of the state’s most iconic fishing towns, also inspiring artists and writers as well as visitors. The new Gloucester Harborwalk takes you on a walk through the port’s famous history. Kindra Clineff/Mass Office of Travel and Tourism Fullscreen Michigan - The state has more lighthouses than any state in the nation. Forty Mile Point Light near Rogers City is just one of more than 129 lighthouses across the Great Lakes. Pure Michigan Fullscreen Minnesota - Lake of the Woods, the nation’s seventh-largest lake, stretches across the Minnesota-Canadian border, cutting off a tiny slice of America. Paul Stafford, Explore Minnesota Tourism Fullscreen Mississippi - There’s much more to the Mississippi Gulf Coast than gaming and nightlife. If you’re looking to get away from it all, take a trip to Ship Island: You might start to imagine you are basking in the sun on some isolated tropical isle. Visit Mississippi Fullscreen Missouri - Take an adventure into the deep when you scuba dive at Bonne Terre Mine. The once-abandoned lead mine now serves as an underwater time capsule, complete with a submerged locomotive to explore Missouri Division of Tourism Fullscreen Montana - Montana is known as the Treasure State for its abundance of mineral deposits and gemstones, one of which is the Yogo Sapphire, mined near Lewistown in the Little Belt Mountains. Donnie Sexton, Montana Office of Tourism Fullscreen Nebraska - Toadstool Geologic Park is located in northwestern Nebraska and is named after its unusual “moonscape” rock formations. Nebraska Tourism Fullscreen Nevada - Great Basin National Park in eastern Nevada has stunning mountain terrain, an extensive cave system and 5,000-year-old bristlecone pines that make it a must see. travelnevada.com Fullscreen New Hampshire - Boulder Field at Pawtuckaway State Park in Nottingham was created when glacial ice melted near the end of the Ice Age. Jerry and Marcy Monkman/NH Division of Parks and Recreation Fullscreen New Jersey - Branch Brook Park has the largest collection of cherry blossoms in the nation with 5,300 cherry trees. Harry Prott Fullscreen New Mexico - Capulin Volcano is a National Monument, and a great example of nature's awesome power as well as human history in the surrounding areas. rkpphoto, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen New York - The Old City Hall Station has been closed for 69 years, but its arched antiqued ceilingscan briefly be seenif you take the 6 train around the City Hall loop. Marc A. Hermann, MTA New York City Transit Fullscreen North Carolina - Built in the 1920s as a hunting club on the Currituck Sound, Whalehead offers visitors a glimpse of maritime heritage. VisitNC.com Fullscreen North Dakota - Jamestown is home to the extremely rare albino bison that graze near the National Buffalo Museum. Bill Tanata Fullscreen Ohio - From their tiny home atop Liberty Hill, 100 steps up from the town of Ripley on the Ohio River, Reverend John Rankin and his family risked their safety to help escaping slaves to freedom on the front lines of the Underground Railroad. Tourism Ohio Fullscreen Oklahoma - The 77-foot waterfall at Natural Falls State Park is accompanied by several smaller falls that flow from the porous walls of a fern-covered rock face. Keli Clark/Oklahoma Tourism Fullscreen Oregon - When you travel to the off-the-beaten path Painted Hills in Eastern Oregon, you can see millions of years of history revealed in the layers of mountains of earth, one color at a time. Christian Heeb/Travel Oregon Fullscreen Pennsylvania - Among Philadelphia’s many claims to fame is Elfreth’s Alley, America’s oldest continuously residential street that dates back to the first days of the eighteenth century. Elfreth's Alley Fullscreen Rhode Island - The Daffodil fields on Block Island at Clayhead Trail are only in bloom for about one month and are hard to find, which keeps it under the radar but oh-so-worth-it. Block Island Tourism Fullscreen South Carolina - Explore Caesars Head State Park for scenic views of South Carolina’s mountainous Upstate. DiscoverSouthCarolina.com Fullscreen South Dakota - Nestled in the magnificent Spearfish Canyon is Devil’s Bathtub, a refreshing reward at the end of a family-friendly hike in the Black Hills of South Dakota. South Dakota Dept of Tourism Fullscreen Tennessee - Bluegrass Underground is a concert that is put on in the Volcano Room of Cumberland Caverns in McMinnville. Artists like Vince Gill, Old Crow Medicine Show, and Amos Lee have all played the venue. Tennessee Dept of Tourist Development Fullscreen Texas - Austin lays claim to the largest urban bat population in North America. Watch the nightly emergence from the Statesman Bat Observation Center Aneese, Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Utah – Capitol Reef National Park is an under-the-radar national park in Utah. Utah Office of Tourism Fullscreen Vermont - The Millstone Trails in Websterville wind through 50 historic granite quarry sites, providing great access for biking, walking, hiking, snowshoeing and Nordic skiing. VermontVacation.com Fullscreen Virginia - Big Stone Gapis a city in Southwest Virginia as well as the title of a book byAdriana Trigiani. Jason Barnette/Virginia Tourism Corporation, www.Virginia.org Fullscreen Washington - The San Juan Island National Historical Park (with two camps located on opposite sides of the island)offers miles of hiking, biking and horseback riding trails. DH Fullscreen West Virginia - Beneath the luxurious Greenbrier resort in White Sulphur Springs exists a 112,544-square-foot bunker that was built during the Cold War to shelter government officials. Greenbrier Resort Bunker Fullscreen Wisconsin - Guests can stay overnight at Still Bend (Bernard Schwartz House)in Two Rivers, a Life Magazine “Dream House” designed by famed architect and Wisconsin native, Frank Lloyd Wright. Michael Ditmer Fullscreen Wyoming - If you head east on Second Avenue through the town of Afton, you’ll reach Intermittent Spring. Called “the spring that breathes” by Native Americans, it is the largest of only three fluctuating springs known in the world. Wyoming Office of Tourism Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Scenic spots:
Alabama - Caney Creek Falls in the Bankhead National Forest in north Alabama makes for a beautiful stop. Keith Bozeman Fullscreen Alaska - Mount McKinley, North America’s tallest mountain, is a sight to see. Abbie Bonney Fullscreen Arizona - One of Arizona's most-photographed backdrops is Red Rock Crossing in Sedona. Arizona Office of Tourism Fullscreen Arkansas - The country's first national river, the scenic Buffalo, flows roughly 150 miles through the Arkansas Ozarks. Arkansas Tourism Fullscreen California - The Bixby Creek Arch Bridge in Big Sur, Calif, showcases some of America's most beautiful land. Visit California/Blaise Fullscreen Colorado - While the Maroon Bells near Aspen are touted as the most photographed place in Colorado, pictures simply don’t do the peaks justice. Matt Inden, Colorado Tourism Office Fullscreen Connecticut - Located at the eastern point of New Haven Harbor, Lighthouse Point has extended a warm welcome to ships and sailors for almost a century. Connecticut Office of Tourism Fullscreen Delaware - There’s a majesty in the sounds of the sea, wind and shorebirds – and unmatched view – along “The Point” at Cape Henlopen State Park. VisitDelaware.com Fullscreen Florida - With 825 miles of sparkling beaches, Florida offers plenty of ways to snag some R&R, especially in the Tampa-St. Pete area Visit Florida Fullscreen Georgia - Take the scenic drive on Georgia’s Hwy 52 near the Cohutta Wilderness. It leads visitors to the beautifully secluded getaway of Fort Mountain State Park. Georgia Tourism Fullscreen Hawaii - Sunrise view from Kalahaku Lookout on top of Haleakala Crater. NPS Photo Fullscreen Idaho - The view from atop Schweitzer Mountain includes three mountain ranges. Schweitzer Mountain Resort Fullscreen Illinois - Beginning in Chicago, Route 66 in Illinois is filled with more must-see Americana than anywhere else, like the world’s largest Route 66 mural in Pontiac. EnjoyIllinois.com Fullscreen Indiana - The south shore of Lake Michigan in Indiana is ranked as one of the top five family beaches in the country. VisitIndiana.com Fullscreen Iowa - Mt. Hosmer in Lansing, Iowa, provides a panoramic view of the Mississippi River. Iowa Tourism Office Fullscreen Kansas - For a breathtaking and unexpected view, take in the sunset at Monument Rocks National Natural Landmark near Oakley, Kan.
